column6: "reviewText": "The LI Embassy Guide isn't a bad piece of work but it sure isn't the definitive reference book that it purports to be. Generally speaking
column7: the guide can find something charming and optimistic to say about every harbor and you can count on the fact that advertisers are portrayed in terms that glow. This makes things like restaurant recommendations highly suspect
column8: and some disappointing meals confirm that suspicion. The guide is most useful for its collection of charts that give the data on harbor facilities
column9: largely accurate and definitely helpful. Conclusion: buy it for its factual information

column6: "reviewText": "I have been attempting to use DeLorme Topo North America 10 for a number of months.  I have a very simple task; just select a point on a trail
column7: then another point on the same trail
column8: and use the trail as a route.  DeLorme let me do it
column9: once.  Every other time I've tried
column10: it just connects the two points with a straight line on the 2-D map and won't let me change it.  It does still allow me to delete the route
column11: but that isn't much help.There are at least three different ways of creating a route using an existing trail
column12: but all of them do the same thing; a straight line from endpoint to endpoint.  If I add points in between
column13: it just connects them with straight line segments.  Theoretically
column14: I suppose I could enter a large number of points in between and get something that resembles the actual trail length.Sometimes
column16: it highlights the trail that I'm trying to get it to use as a route
column17: but won't keep it as the route.  The tutorials and help pages all say that what I'm doing will use the trail as my route.  The software denies that claim.I've gone to the technical support website repeatedly
column18: and the one concrete thing that I've learned is that I might as well watch television instead; it's just as useful and less irritating.  Technical support is a series of articles none of which have anything to do with the topic that I've searched.  If it has the phrase I've entered
column19: it presents the article.  It even ignores anything that I've entered regarding which product I'm actually trying to get information on
column21: regardless of what product the article is referring to.  With the large number of products that DeLorme has
column22: you've got to love that!I made the mistake of buying the product directly from DeLorme
column23: and it is so complicated to learn how to use it
column24: that the return period had long expired before I figured out that the problem was DeLorme
column27: "summary": "DeLorme North America 10 and their Technical support is a joke."

column6: "reviewText": "Have owned a PN40 for some time.  Decided to upgraded to Topo North America 10.0 with the PN regional map disks.  Started to load some of the states that I am interested in to the PN and there is a disk error.  Went to the technical support website where the problem is acknowledged and you are given the opportunity to sit through a forty minute download to put one state's detail on the PN.  What a pain.  Contacted DeLorme and am told that the disk has not been remastered since I bought the software (2013 software purchased in May of 2014 from their store in Yarmouth) and that all I would get is another defective disk.  REALLY?  You haven't fixed this problem in a year and have corrected disks available for those who request them?  You think that your sales person in Yarmouth might have mentioned the defect?  In other words
column7: DeLorme told me to go pound sand and download what I needed.  Not what I signed up for.  If I wasn't stuck with already owning the PN40
column8: I would return the software.  This experience and other comments regarding poor user interface and functions makes me think that my next GPS won't come from DeLorme."

column6: "reviewText": "Thankfully I checked this video out from my local library.  This video is supposed to be for people who are already familiar with the Primary series
column7: but it is very instructional.  This video seems to go very very slowly... maybe it is just Richard Freeman's voice
column8: which drones on and on and on... I seriously could not finish past sun salutation "A".  I don't know how anyone could actually finish the whole hour and a half.  As for the other reviewers who say that Richard is much more "spiritual" than David Swenson
column9: I don't know where they are coming from; there is nothing spiritual about "opening up your buttocks" or "pressing your pubic bone forward"
column10: or "open the groin with enthusiasm?"  Maybe he is trying to sound spiritual or relaxing
column11: but his voice would irritatingly put me to sleep.  If you are looking for a good primary series
column12: go with David Swenson.  He is enthusiastic
column13: instructional and doesn't do too much chattering.  Not to mention
column14: he is very good at what he does as well as inspiring."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a good video in many ways
column7: but I thought \"Primary Series\" meant more of the beginner mode (especially since he has an intermediate series)and many of the poses here are very advanced.  I had to laugh when he put both his feet behind his head and then balanced on his hands and laid his chest on the floor and said \"this may take you a few weeks of practice to do...\"  I was thinking a few years or decades!  Many of the poses are wonderful but what I would need for this to be better is for him to tell me what to do when I could not do a pose
column9: what muscles and joints are not allowing me to do it and what should I do now in order to get them in shape to be able to do that pose down the line."

column6: "reviewText": "Are you kidding me?  This is for beginners?  This is for beginning contorsionists!!  Sure I can handle a few of the yoga stances
column7: like breathing and "statahititi".  I almost had to call out of work today because I can not remove my leg from the back of my head.  I will admit that this type of yoga kept me "regular" as far as peristalsis goes!I do not recommend for a beginner or intermediate."

column6: "reviewText": "I practice Ashtanga Yoga as well as Jivamukti and enjoy vinyasa flow. However
column8: while clearly a major force in Ashtanga yoga
column9: does not do it for me in this video. I found his tape torturous to sit through
column10: uninteresting and lacking in any connection with his audience. David Swensons' series in my opinion is much more successful in relaying the overall "feeling" of Ashtanga yoga as well as providing encouragement and an understanding of how yoga might best be practiced. My Richard Freeman tape gathers dust while Mr. Swenson's tapes are rewound daily. Peace and Love."
column12: "summary": "Not the flow I was looking for..."

column6: "reviewText": "Matt clearly takes pride in his endeavors; yet
column7: he showed no attempt to apply this work ethic to presenting knowledge. The look and feel of this book
column11: all are horrible. This is true for all of his books and videos.I believe Matt wants us to believe he is trying to match his products to his crass persona...and that would be fine. But the truth is his books and videos are simply unprofessional. They lack good topical structure
column12: information presentation
column13: etc. Basically
column14: there is a general lack of respect for books and video creation.So why three stars? Because content is king! And Furey's books/videos have rock solid and usable content. Most of his exercises work. Period. And his advice
column16: is more solid than most polished fitness books.Again
column17: there is nothing wrong with having a crass persona. We all love Mickey (from Rocky)
column18: but 'Mickey' was delivered via fantastic actors
column21: and directors.Matt's philosophy (psycho-cybernetics) allowed him to be a champion wrestler and very skilled speaker and advertiser. He just needs to apply himself more toward his books/videos."
column23: "summary": "Don't judge a book by its cover"
